title: How to Make Blackened Cajun Halibut

steps.headline: Clarify the butter.
steps.description: Slowly melt the butter in the small saucepan, it will separate. There will be a 'skin' on the top, remove this and discard. The only part needed is the clear butterfat, spoon this into a small dish and reserve. The milky liquid layer in the bottom of the pan can also be discarded.

steps.headline: Make the seasoning.
steps.description: Just mix all of the dry ingredients in a small bowl.

steps.headline: Trim your fillets.
steps.description: This step may not be necessary. As long as the fillets are no longer than the skillet, and about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick, leave them be.

steps.headline: Heat the skillet over an open fire, or over a burner.
steps.description: Don't worry about it getting too hot, it's not possible. This should take about 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Prepare the fillets.
steps.description: Brush each side heavily with the clarified butter, then season with the mixed dry ingredients.

steps.headline: Once the skillet is screaming hot, carefully lay the fillets in with a long handled spatula.
steps.description: Don't crowd them. It is best to only cook one or two at a time. Be careful here, as you lay the fillet in the pan, it is likely to flare up.

steps.headline: Spoon some of the butter over the top of the fish.
Cook for 1-2 minutes.
steps.description: It's ready to turn when the bottom is charred. Be careful not to overcook them, or the fish will taste burned rather than blackened.

steps.headline: Flip the fillets.
steps.description: Again, spoon butter over the tops to keep the fish moist.

steps.headline: Serve your amazing Cajun Halibut.
steps.description: These are delicious with rice and steamed vegetables, or baked potatoes and roasted vegetables. Experiment to find your favorite meal.

text: Clarify the butter. Slowly melt the butter in the small saucepan, it will separate. There will be a 'skin' on the top, remove this and discard. The only part needed is the clear butterfat, spoon this into a small dish and reserve. The milky liquid layer in the bottom of the pan can also be discarded. Make the seasoning. Just mix all of the dry ingredients in a small bowl. Trim your fillets. This step may not be necessary. As long as the fillets are no longer than the skillet, and about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick, leave them be. Heat the skillet over an open fire, or over a burner. Don't worry about it getting too hot, it's not possible. This should take about 10 minutes. Prepare the fillets. Brush each side heavily with the clarified butter, then season with the mixed dry ingredients. Once the skillet is screaming hot, carefully lay the fillets in with a long handled spatula. Don't crowd them. It is best to only cook one or two at a time. Be careful here, as you lay the fillet in the pan, it is likely to flare up. Spoon some of the butter over the top of the fish.  Cook for 1-2 minutes. It's ready to turn when the bottom is charred. Be careful not to overcook them, or the fish will taste burned rather than blackened. Flip the fillets. Again, spoon butter over the tops to keep the fish moist. Repeat with the remaining fillets.  Serve your amazing Cajun Halibut. These are delicious with rice and steamed vegetables, or baked potatoes and roasted vegetables. Experiment to find your favorite meal.
